query:
Write a Related Works section for an academic paper given the paper's abstract. Here is the paper abstract:
Multi-Domain Recommendation (MDR) achieves the desirable recommendation
performance by effectively utilizing the transfer information across different
domains. Despite the great success, most existing MDR methods adopt a single
structure to transfer complex domain-shared knowledge. However, the beneficial
transferring information should vary across different domains. When there is
knowledge conflict between domains or a domain is of poor quality,
unselectively leveraging information from all domains will lead to a serious
Negative Transfer Problem (NTP). Therefore, how to effectively model the
complex transfer relationships between domains to avoid NTP is still a
direction worth exploring. To address these issues, we propose a simple and
dynamic Similar Domain Selection Principle (SDSP) for multi-domain
recommendation in this paper. SDSP presents the initial exploration of
selecting suitable domain knowledge for each domain to alleviate NTP.
Specifically, we propose a novel prototype-based domain distance measure to
effectively model the complexity relationship between domains. Thereafter, the
proposed SDSP can dynamically find similar domains for each domain based on the
supervised signals of the domain metrics and the unsupervised distance measure
from the learned domain prototype. We emphasize that SDSP is a lightweight
method that can be incorporated with existing MDR methods for better
performance while not introducing excessive time overheads. To the best of our
knowledge, it is the first solution that can explicitly measure domain-level
gaps and dynamically select appropriate domains in the MDR field. Extensive
experiments on three datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed
method.

nuggets.text: Multi-Domain Recommendation (MDR) leverages knowledge transfer across domains
Most SS-based methods use a single domain-shared module
Single shared modules struggle with complex multi-domain knowledge transfer
Negative Transfer Problem (NTP) arises from unselective domain knowledge transfer
SDSP introduces a dynamic, lightweight domain selection module for MDR
SDSP uses a prototype-based domain distance measure to model domain relationships
SDSP dynamically selects similar domains for each target domain
SDSP alleviates NTP by explicit domain-level gap measurement and selection
SDSP is the first MDR solution to explicitly measure and select domains
Extensive experiments validate SDSP's effectiveness on multiple datasets
Classical single-domain recommendation methods cannot handle multi-domain data
MDR methods address cold-start and data sparsity issues
Shared-Specific (SS) and Dynamic Weight (DW) are main MDR modeling paradigms
SS-based methods use shared-bottom with domain-specific towers
DW-based methods generate scenario-sensitive weighted parameters
DW-based methods rely on manual feature selection, limiting generalization
Selection problems in MDR are combinatorially complex and discrete
Greedy-based selection algorithms incur high overhead, unsuitable for time-sensitive MDR
Single gating mechanisms are insufficient for complex multi-domain scenarios
SDSP can be incorporated into existing MDR methods with minimal overhead
